keyTakeAways: The death toll from flooding in central and southeastern Mexico has risen to 44, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting a higher figure of 48, and dozens still missing.
Floods were triggered by heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which affected five states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
Specific fatalities include 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Approximately 320,000 people have experienced power outages, and at least 16,000 homes have been damaged.
The Mexican government has mobilized the military to assist in rescue operations and aid distribution, with rescue workers evacuating residents using life rafts and navigating waist-high floodwaters.
The flooding is part of a broader pattern of extreme rainfall in Mexico this year, with Mexico City recording its rainiest June in over two decades.

Authorities suspect the recent rains were due to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which dumped heavy rainfall on western Mexico, with the remnants of Raymond expected to reach southern Baja California.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding in central and southeastern Mexico, caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, has led to at least 44 confirmed deaths and dozens missing. The disaster affected five states—Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi—with the highest fatalities in Veracruz and Hidalgo. Around 320,000 people lost power, and 16,000 homes were damaged. President Claudia Sheinbaum called for military mobilization to support rescue operations and aid distribution, with photos showing evacuations and flooded homes. The event is linked to a broader trend of extreme rainfall in Mexico this year, including Mexico City’s rainiest June in over two decades.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
